document.docAuthor: Barbero, Enrico, Palestrini, Claudia & Roggero, Angela
document.masterDocTitle: Tibiodrepanus tagliaferrii — a new Afrotropical Drepanocerina species (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Oniticellini), with notes on phylogeny and distribution of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Tibiodrepanus tagliaferrii — a new Afrotropical Drepanocerina species (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Oniticellini), with notes on phylogeny and distribution of the genus

bibRefCitation.author: Laporte
bibRefCitation.refString: Laporte, F. L. (as le Compte de Castelnau) (1840) Histoire naturelle des Animaux Articules. Insectes et Coleopteres. Dumenil, Paris, 564 pp.

bibRefCitation.author: Boheman
bibRefCitation.refString: Boheman, C. H. (1857) Insecta Caffrariae annis 1838 - 1845 a J. A. Wahlberg collecta. Pars 2. Coleoptera. Fritze & Norstedt, Stockholm, 395 pp.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype : 3 , “
SOUTH AFRICA :
Cape Prov., George, Saasveld n° 192 , Breytenbach” ( TMSA ).

Additional material examined. We examined more than
350 specimens
of
T. sulcicollis
. We excluded specimens with a label that are considered too generic (see remarks for further information). The number of individuals for each locality is given within brackets.

Diagnosis. This species can be easily identified by the protibiae bearing four normally shaped outer teeth. This characteristic is unique for the genus.

Distribution. Mali , Ivory Coast , Senegal , Togo , Benin , Gabon , Ghana , Burkina Faso , Gambia , Guinea , Cameroon , Congo , Democratic Republic of Congo , Ethiopia , Uganda , Kenya , Tanzania , Burundi , Rwanda , Angola , Mozambique and South Africa .

Remarks. The species was described by
Laporte ( 1840 )
and included in the genus
Oniticellus
, but soon afterwards was transferred to
Drepanocerus
by
Harold ( 1869 )
.
Drepanocerus dispar
was described by
Boheman ( 1857 )
from Eastern Cape province, South Africa and then synonymized with
D. sulcicollis
by
Harold ( 1869 )
. The species was included in
Sulcodrepanus
by
Krikken ( 2009 )
. We excluded specimens with a label that was considered too generic, such as specimens labeled “Sammers Jan
7 .i. 1884
” ( SANC ), or “ South Africa , Great Karoo” ( OUMNH ), or “Caffraria” ( ZMUC ). Furthermore, we are sure that the data from Vaseli, Bulgaria (
15 specimens
, NHMB ) are erroneous.
